_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: Removed fixed storage tanks from site
_prev_prog_2.Description: This facility complies with the rules and regulations governing the storage and handling of the covered materials.  Inspections, maintenance and employee training are important components of our accident prevention program

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1. The Facility Policy

The owners, management, and employees of Seward Ag. Supply Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Seward Fire Department, Winnebago Co. LEPC or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.  The fixed storage tanks were removed from service 8-28-2008.  

2. Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

The primary activity at the facility is the storage and blending of fertilizers, farm chemicals and related agricultural products, for sale to the farmer.

The maximum quantity of Anhydrous Ammonia stored would be 302,000 in our nurse tanks parked at the facility. The maximum quantity handled in the largest tank would be 6,776 # in our largest nurse tank(s)

3. The Worst-Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Release Scenario.

Worse-Case:  The worse-case scenario is not disclosed for security.

Alternative Case:  The alternative release scenario is not disclosed for security.

4. The Accidental Release Prevention Program

This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydours Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards, Institute, Inc., and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

5. The Five-year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of Anhydrous Ammonia (from our fixed sources) in the past five years that: have caused deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at this facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damages. A release from a delivery tanker occurred in April 2007 responsibility for the release was the transport operator's.

6. The Emergency Response Program

This facility has a current Emergency Action Plan ( in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38) in place and has coordinated this program with  Tim Snellson of Niantic Fire Department and with Phillip Amello of Macon Co. LEPC.  We train our staff on the elements found in our response program (in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.120) and have invited the fire department to visit our facility in order to provide them with a working knowledge of our plant's layout and our storage facility. This facility has provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
